conclusion: Two light bulbs emit red and yellow light at different depths, creating the same illuminated area on the water surface.
Refractive indices for red and yellow light are n₁ and n₂ respectively.
The task is to find the area of the light-emitting area of a light bulb.
Snell's law: n₁sin(θ₁) = n₂sin(θ₂) governs light refraction from water to air.
Total internal reflection occurs beyond a critical angle; only light within this angle escapes the water surface.
Critical angle for red light: θc₁ = arcsin(1/n₁).
Critical angle for yellow light: θc₂ = arcsin(1/n₂).
Radius of illuminated area for red light: r₁ = h₁·tan(arcsin(1/n₁)).
Radius of illuminated area for yellow light: r₂ = hB·tan(arcsin(1/n₂)).
Area of illuminated circle: A = π·h²·tan²(arcsin(1/n)).
Equation for equal areas: π·h₁²·tan²(arcsin(1/n₁)) = π·hB²·tan²(arcsin(1/n₂)).
Depth of yellow light bulb: hB = h₁·tan(arcsin(1/n₁))/tan(arcsin(1/n₂)).
Light-emitting area corresponds to the base of the cone of light reaching the surface.
Area of light-emitting source: A_source = π·h²·tan²(θc).
Final answer: The light-emitting area for both bulbs is π·h₁²·tan²(arcsin(1/n₁)).
